sections.title: Values
sections.content:
Values

A value is either a literal or the result of a computation, that may
be stored in a memory location, and interpreted based on some type.

An allocated object is a value stored at some memory address.

The base address of an allocated object is the memory address where
the object is stored.

An [allocated object]s memory size is the number of bytes the object
spans in memory from its base address.

Two [value]s overlap when

* Both [value]s are the same, or

* One value is of an abstract data type and the other denotes a
 field of the same value, or

* One value denotes an array and the other denotes an element of the
 same value, or

* Both [value]s are elements of the same array.

It is undefined behavior to create a value from uninitialized memory unless
the type of the value is a union type.

It is undefined behavior to create an allocated object at base address
null.

It is undefined behavior to create an allocated object with memory
size size at a base address base where base + size is greater
than the architectures maximum usize value.

It is undefined behavior to create an allocated object with memory
size size where size is greater than the architectures maximum
isize value.

sections.title: Constants
sections.content:
Constants

 ConstantInitializer ::=
 $$=$$ Expression

A constant is an immutable value expression whose uses are substituted by
the value.

An unnamed constant is a constant declared with character 0x5F (low
line).

The type specification of a constant shall have 'static
lifetime.

The type of a constant shall implement the core::marker::Sized
trait.

A constant initializer is a construct that provides the value of
its related constant.

A constant shall have a constant initializer, unless it is an
associated trait constant.

The expression of a constant initializer shall be a
constant expression.

The value of a constant is determined by evaluating its
constant initializer.

After type coercion, the value of the constant cannot contain any
[mutable reference]s, except when

- The mutable reference is contained within an external static, or

- The mutable reference is contained within a mutable static, or

- The mutable reference is contained within a static
 whose type is subject to interior mutability, or

- The mutable reference is contained within an union, or

- The referent is a value of a zero-sized type.

The elaboration of a constant evaluates its constant initializer.

A path that refers to a constant is replaced with the value of
the constant.

sections.title: Statics
sections.content:
Statics

 StaticInitializer ::=
 $$=$$ Expression

A static is a value that is associated with a specific memory
location.

A static defined within a generic function exists once in the
output executable or library.

The type specification of a static shall have 'static
lifetime.

The type of a static shall implement the core::marker::Sized
trait.

A static shall only be subject to an ItemSafety if it is an external static in an unsafe external block.

A mutable static is a static with keyword mut whose
value can be modified.

Access to a mutable static shall require unsafe context.

An immutable static is a static whose value cannot be modified.

The type of an immutable static shall implement the
core::marker::Sync trait.

A static initializer is a construct that provides the value of
its related static.

A static shall have a static initializer, unless it is an
external static.

The expression of a static initializer shall be a
constant expression.

A use of a static is a place expression referring to the unique
location of the static.

The elaboration of a static evaluates its static initializer.

All [path]s that refer to a static refer to the same memory location.

A static is not dropped during destruction.

An immutable static whose type is not subject to
interior mutability may reside in read-only memory.

It is undefined behavior to mutate an immutable static whose type is
not subject to interior mutability.

sections.title: Temporaries
sections.content:
Temporaries

A temporary is an anonymous variable produced by some intermediate
computation.

paragraphs.fls_awpw61yofckz: A temporary is an anonymous variable produced by some intermediate computation.

sections.title: Variables
sections.content:
Variables

A variable is a placeholder for a value that is allocated on the
stack.

The following [construct]s are [variable]s:

* A binding.

* A temporary.

A variable shall be used only after it has been initialized through all
[reachable control flow path]s up to the point of its usage.

A variable is not initialized when allocated.

sections.title: Constant Promotion
sections.content:
Constant Promotion

Constant promotion is the process of converting a value expression
into a constant.

Constant promotion is possible only when

* The value expression is a constant expression, and

* The type of the value expression does not have a destructor,
 and

* The value expression does not employ a struct expression
 constructing a core::cell::UnsafeCell, and

* The value expression only consists of operations that will always succeed
 evaluation, and

* The value expression is the operand of an
 immutable borrow expression.

Constant promotion is always possible for expression &mut [],
promoting the produced mutable borrow to have 'static lifetime.

Constant promotion proceeds as follows:

#. An anonymous constant is created, whose constant initializer holds
 the result of the value expression.

#. The value of the anonymous constant is borrowed with
 'static lifetime.
